importantDates.descriptionOfWhyDateIsRelevant: The date of the news article, indicating when the incident involving live artillery fire over a highway at Camp Pendleton was reported.
The date when the incident occurred during weekend exercises observed by Vice President JD Vance and reported by state authorities.
The date when the Marine Corps and California Highway Patrol confirmed the incident and suspended further firing.

importantTimeframes.descriptionOfWhyTimeFrameIsRelevant: The exercise took place over the weekend, with the incident occurring during Saturday’s live fire drills at Camp Pendleton.

keyTakeAways: Live artillery rounds were fired over Interstate 5 during a Marine Corps exercise at Camp Pendleton, causing metal shrapnel to fall and damage a California Highway Patrol vehicle.
No injuries were reported, but the incident raised safety concerns.
Governor Gavin Newsom strongly objected to the firing, temporarily closing a 17-mile stretch of I-5 for safety.
The Marine Corps claimed the exercise was safe and that firing was within established protocols, though a possible airborne detonation occurred outside the designated impact area.
An investigation has been launched to determine the root cause of the premature detonation.
Vice President JD Vance observed the drills, which were held to commemorate the 250th birthday of the Marine Corps.
Marine Corps spokesperson Capt. Gregory Dreibelbis confirmed that firing was suspended and no injuries occurred.
A piece of shrapnel was found on a patrol officer's motorcycle and another on an unoccupied patrol vehicle, causing minor damage.

namedEntities.name: Gavin Newsom
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: He strongly objected to the live firing over Interstate 5, citing public safety concerns and closed a 17-mile stretch of the highway, making him a central figure in the controversy.

namedEntities.name: JD Vance
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: Vice President of the United States
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: He observed the live-fire exercise at Camp Pendleton, raising public and political controversy over the safety of such drills in populated areas.

namedEntities.name: Camp Pendleton
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: U.S. Marine Corps Base in California
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: The site where the live-fire drills took place, where a premature artillery detonation occurred and where the exercise was being conducted to mark the Marine Corps’ 250th anniversary.

namedEntities.name: Interstate 5
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: The highway over which live artillery rounds were fired, leading to shrapnel damage and public safety concerns, prompting Governor Newsom to shut down a 17-mile stretch of it.

namedEntities.name: 155 mm artillery round
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: Type of artillery shell used in the exercise
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: The shell detonated prematurely overhead, causing shrapnel to fall and damage a patrol vehicle, indicating a possible technical or procedural failure.

namedEntities.name: Captain Gregory Dreibelbis
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: He confirmed that the firing was suspended due to a possible airborne detonation and stated that no injuries occurred, emphasizing the Marine Corps' commitment to safety.

namedEntities.name: California Highway Patrol (CHP)
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: State law enforcement agency in California
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: The agency reported the shrapnel damage, closed the highway, and documented the incident, playing a key role in public safety enforcement.

namedEntities.name: Marine Corps 250th Birthday
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: The drills were conducted to mark the 250th anniversary of the Marine Corps, providing context for the timing and political significance of the exercise.

summaryOfNewsArticle: During a live-fire exercise at Camp Pendleton to commemorate the 250th birthday of the U.S. Marine Corps, a 155 mm artillery round prematurely detonated overhead, sending metal shrapnel that damaged a California Highway Patrol vehicle and struck an officer’s motorcycle. The incident occurred on Saturday, prompting Governor Gavin Newsom to close a 17-mile stretch of Interstate 5 for safety. Despite the Marine Corps asserting that the exercise was safe and within protocols, a possible airborne detonation outside the designated area led to the immediate suspension of firing. No injuries were reported, but an investigation has been launched. Vice President JD Vance observed the drills, which sparked bipartisan controversy over public safety and political risk-taking. The event underscored tensions between military readiness demonstrations and civilian safety concerns.
title: Plan to fire artillery over a highway during Vance visit irks California’s Newsom
